top_comments:

>Interior Minister Pance Toskovski said initial reports suggested the fire started from sparks caused by pyrotechnic devices.
Speaking outside the Kocani police station, he said the sparks had hit the ceiling, which was made of highly flammable material.

Yeah that's a frightening lapse in safety, and it's sad so many people died because of it.

We had something similar in Romania a few years ago. The whole thing was also a big signal for deep corruption:  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colectiv_nightclub_fire The fire started almost identically to what's in this Reuters article. A lot of people died during the crowd crush at the single smallish exit. Many others died after the fire due to injuries (burns) and infections.

It is so eerie how literally the same thing happened 10 years ago in Romania, at club "Colectiv". Pyrotechnics, highly inflamabile ceiling, poorly managed exits. 64 people died and 146 were severely injured, countless lives and families ruined. It is the deadliest fire accident in Romanian history and one of our biggest national tragedies.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colectiv_nightclub_fire

Here's a video of the moment the fire starts (warning: disturbing). https://youtu.be/t-Cgw4jj0u8

The macedonian fire looks like an exact copy of this..
Not only do you have the same safety lapses as The Station, but you're called Pulse. It's like you're asking to have your patrons massacred.
What a fucking mess. Rip to the victims.

Based on the comments, there have been at least four deadly fires in nightclubs (before this one) that were because of indoor pyrotechnics:

The Station nightclub fire in West Warwick, Rhode Island, USA on February 20, 2003. Deaths: 100.

The Lame Horse nightclub fire in Perm, Russia, on December 5, 2009. Deaths: 156.

The Kiss nightclub fire in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, on January 27, 2013. Deaths: 242.

The Colectiv nightclub fire in Bucharest, Romania, on October 30, 2015. Deaths: 64.
